results.title: Martin Chuzzlewit
results.creator_credit: Pedr James, Chris Parr, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description: Charles Dickens’ classic tale is brought to the screen with an excellent cast of Paul Scofield, John Mills, Pete Postlethwaite, Tom Wilkinson and Julia Sawalha. Martin Chuzzlewit is a very wealthy old man. Having disinherited his grandson Martin, he only trusts his companion, the orphan Mary Graham, employed on the understanding that she will get no money. With a fortune to grasp, Chuzzlewit’s family bring forth all their cunning, greed and selfishness. There is the snivelling hypocrite Pecksniff with his two daughters Mercy and Charity and the evil Jonas who will resort to murder to gain the money.

results.title: Martin Bartfeld and Bruce McGuinness filming A Time to Dream in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: Martin Arnold: cinemnesis
results.brief_description: Martin Arnold is a contemporary Austrian experimental filmmaker. His short films make use of familiar Hollywood footage put through an optical printer to create effects of jarring, twitching and rhythmic vision. The sequence is stoped and started over and over from one frame and incrementally moves slowly ahead in a jumping fashion. The effect is nervous and jumpy and allows the viewer to contemplate further in an abstract fashion the notion of film and the ideas of memory and machinery. The ideas of Freud along with other thinkers like Derrida have informed the filmmaker. Ideas about memory and what is etched into the brain being in fact a vision which is clear and yet highly effected by emotions, places and thoughts. Displacing and decontextualising recognisable found footage causes the stable and reassuring images to become mildly disturbing. The human condition becomes technical and the nature of film is altered as what we thought of as mundane and everyday is oddly out of context. These short films are interesting and at the same time cause a mild discomfort.

results.title: Martha Clarke: light and dark
results.brief_description: The film portrays an artist’s imaginative sources, and the processes through which she creates an evening of theatrical dance. The film departs from traditional dance films by looking behind the finished performance to its imaginative sources and the process by which the performance grows.
results.description: The film portrays an artist’s imaginative sources, and the processes through which she creates an evening of theatrical dance. results.title: Martha
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Peter Marthesheimer
results.brief_description: After Martha Heyer’s tyrannical father dies suddenly during their holiday in Italy, she meets and is proposed to by engineer Helmut Salomon, who sweeps her off her feet with a disturbing mixture of romance and intimidation. After their marriage Helmut’s behaviour becomes increasingly oppressive and Martha’s ever more fearful and desperate to please, as the film builds to a truly horrific climax. Whether taken as a psychological horror movie or as the blackest of black comedies, this is undoubtedly the most extreme and alarming of all of Fassbinder’s visions of married life. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Marsupials: Naturally the numbat
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, John Shaw and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: You mean a wombat don’t you? is the usual reaction but a numbat is quite different - smaller than a cat, with a long pointed nose and a striped back. Numbats live inside hollow logs in densely wooded areas, and eat termites. Includes feeding scenes and close-ups of young numbats.

results.title: Marsupial memories
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Allan Vaughan tells the story of a funny looking stuffed kangaroo housed at the Murtoa museum. He recalls how, as a child, he used to visit the kangaroo when it was a pet belonging to his uncle. He tells how his uncle used to box with this kangaroo and also relates the story of how the animal came to end up as a taxidermic display.

results.title: Marshland birds I and II: island builders and shore builders
results.brief_description: A study of many British mainland birds - coots, swans, geese, great-crested grebes, snipe, bittern, moorhens, yellow wagtails, bearded tits, reed warblers, and harriers. Their mating, nesting and the hatching and rearing of their young are studied in detail. These birds represent two main types of marshland birds: island builders, and shore builders, according to where they build their nests.

results.title: Mars the Viking Mission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Looks at the five successful American missions to Mars that have taken place since 1964, discussing how advances in photography have improved scientists’ ability to identify small features on Mars. Also discusses the work performed by two laboratories which have been landed on Mars to analyse soil, test for existence of life and record weather conditions.

results.title: Mars minus myth
results.brief_description: One of the scientists of the Mariner 9 mission presents some of the geological findings of this mission to Mars. Photographs sent back have stripped away much of the myth surrounding the planet, while raising new questions. Discusses the origins of landforms, the discovery of water ice in the polar caps, the improbability of life and other topics.
